title: Cygnus Cargo Ship Enroute to ISS Experiences Propulsion Anomalies
summary: The Northrop Grumman Cygnus cargo ship loaded with 11,000 pounds of experiments and supplies for the International Space Station will not dock tomorrow morning as planned. Launched on Sunday, the […]
detailed_news: NG-23 spacecraft experienced propulsion anomalies today as it raised its orbit to match that of the ISS. NASA and Northrop Grumman are assessing what steps are needed next. A new arrival date is to be determined. NG-23 lifted off on time Sunday evening at 6:11 pm ET aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral.

title: NASA, Northrop Grumman postpone Cygnus XL arrival to ISS following propulsion issue
summary: The spacecraft was originally scheduled to dock with the International Space Station the morning of Wednesday, Sept. 17. An alternate plan is in the works.
detailed_news: Northrop Grumman’s new Cygnus XL spacecraft will no longer dock with the International Space Station Wednesday morning as originally planned. In a blog post Tuesday evening, NASA announced that two, orbit-raising burns of the spacecraft's main engine “stopped earlier than planned” The agency didn’t indicate what may have caused the engine to not perform as expected. Northrop Grumman and SpaceX are the two U.S. companies currently delivering cargo to the ISS as part of the Commercial Resupplies Services 2 contract with NASA. The SpX-33 mission, also referred to as CRS-33, successfully launched from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral on Aug. 24 and autonomously docked to the space station less than 29 hours later. The next cargo mission on the schedule is another new spacecraft called the HTV-X.

title: NASA, Partners Push Forward with Remotely Piloted Airspace Integration
summary: NASA and its partners recently tested a tool for remotely piloted operations that could enable operators to transport people and goods more efficiently within urban areas.   The team’s goal is to ensure that when these remotely piloted aircraft – including electric vertical takeoff and landing vehicles (eVTOLs) – take to the skies, air traffic controllers […]
detailed_news: NASA and its partners recently tested a tool for remotely piloted operations that could enable operators to transport people and goods more efficiently within urban areas. The team’s goal is to ensure that when these remotely Piloted aircraft – including electric vertical takeoff and landing vehicles (eVTOLs) – take to the skies, air traffic controllers won’t be overburdened.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 24 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg SFB
summary: The Starlink 17-12 mission will send the two dozen broadband internet satellites into a polar, low Earth orbit. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 4E at Vandenberg Space Force Base at 8:43 a.m. PDT (11:43 a.m. EDT / 1543 UTC).
detailed_news: The Starlink 17-12 mission is the 83rd mission supporting SpaceX’s megaconstellation so far in 2025. The company aims to launch its Falcon 9 rocket from pad 4E at Vandenberg Space Force Base at 8:43 a.m. PDT. Nearly 8.5 minutes after taking off from the California coast, SpaceX plans to land B1088 on the drone ship ‘Of Course I Still Love You’ If successful, this will be the 152nd landing on this vessel and the 506th booster landing to date.

title: Starship Block 3 development continues at Starbase and McGregor
summary:
SpaceX is gearing up for the next evolution of Starship, with Block 3 hardware on…
The post Starship Block 3 development continues at Starbase and McGregor appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX is gearing up for the next evolution of Starship, with Block 3 hardware on display at Starbase. SpaceX is set to begin launches with the Block 3 vehicle in 2026. Glimpses of Ship 39 are providing visual updates on the Flight 12 vehicle, currently housed in scaffolding within the Starfactory. SpaceX's McGregor, Texas, facility experienced a busy week, with 20 engine tests conducted. Eight involved Raptor engines, while the remainder focused on Merlin engines. A standout achievement occurred on Wednesday at the Raptor South Stand, now dedicated to Raptor 3 variants. The immediate focus remains on the upcoming Flight 11 of Starship, the final launch of the Block 2 vehicle.

detailed_news: Learn about bringing coding and citizen science to your learners. The GLOBE program is a science and education program that focuses on advancing Earth systems science through data collection and analysis by citizen scientists. You’ll learn how students can collect mosquito habitat and land cover data with the free GLOBe Observer app.

title: An Eye-catching Star Cluster
summary: Westerlund 1, the biggest and closest “super” star cluster to Earth, dazzles in this image released on July 23, 2025. This view combines x-ray data from NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory (in pink, blue, purple, and orange), infrared data from NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope (in yellow, gold, and blue), and optical data from NASA’s Hubble […]
detailed_news: Westerlund 1 is the biggest and closest “super” star cluster to Earth. Data from Chandra and other telescopes is helping astronomers delve deeper into this galactic factory. Observations from Chandra have uncovered thousands of individual stars pumping out X-ray emission into the cluster.

title: A new report finds China’s space program will soon equal that of the US
summary: China "poised to overtake us in the next five to 10 years if we don't do something."
detailed_news: A new report looks at China's space ambitions and the threat they pose to the U.S. The report was sponsored by the Commercial Space Federation, which advocates for the country's commercial space industry. The Chinese government made a key decision in 2014, known as "Document 60," that allowed native companies to license government technology and for private capital to be used. The report is named after the wavelength shift of light for objects accelerating away. The bottom line, Cavossa said, is that now represents the last possible opportunity for the United States to make investments. If not, China will soon reach parity and potentially move ahead, hence the decision to name the report.

title: PLD Space Completes MIURA 5 Stage 1 Burst Test
summary:
Spanish rocket builder PLD Space has successfully completed a burst test of a full-scale prototype of its MIURA 5 first stage booster. PLD Space was founded in 2011 and is developing a range of launch vehicles from its small single-stage suborbital MIURA 1 to the multi-booster MIURA Next Super Heavy rocket, which is designed to […]
The post PLD Space Completes MIURA 5 Stage 1 Burst Test appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Spanish rocket builder PLD Space has successfully completed a burst test of a full-scale prototype of its MIURA 5 first stage booster. The test subjected the stage to pressures beyond its intended operating limits to determine the point of structural failure. The company will now proceed with a fully integrated qualification model of the stage that includes all the elements required for flight.

title: Regions on Asteroid Explored by NASA’s Lucy Mission Get Official Names
summary: The IAU (International Astronomical Union), a global naming authority for celestial objects, has approved official names for features on Donaldjohanson, an asteroid NASA’s Lucy spacecraft visited on April 20.
detailed_news: The IAU (International Astronomical Union) has approved official names for features on Donaldjohanson, an asteroid NASA’s Lucy spacecraft visited on April 20. The asteroid was named in 2015 after paleoanthropologist Donald Johanson, discoverer of one of the most famous fossils ever found.

title: How NASA’s Roman Mission Will Unveil Our Home Galaxy Using Cosmic Dust
summary: NASA’s Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will help scientists better understand our Milky Way galaxy’s less sparkly components — gas and dust strewn between stars, known as the interstellar medium. One of Roman’s major observing programs, called the Galactic Plane Survey, will peer through our galaxy to its most distant edge, mapping roughly 20 billion […]
detailed_news: NASA's Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will help scientists better understand our Milky Way galaxy’s less sparkly components. Roman will peer through our galaxy to its most distant edge, mapping roughly 20 billion stars. Scientists will use data from these stars to study and map the dust their light travels through. Roman will identify young clusters of stars in new, distant star-forming regions. Roman’s data will be available to the public online via the Roman Research Nexus and the Barbara A. Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes. Roman is slated to launch no later than May 2027, with a potential early launch as soon as fall 2026.

title: Fly through Gaia’s 3D map of stellar nurseries
summary: Scientists created the most accurate three-dimensional map of star-formation regions in our Milky Way galaxy, based on data from the European Space Agency’s Gaia space telescope. This map will teach us more about these obscure cloudy areas, and the hot young stars that shape them.

title: The most accurate 3D map of stellar nurseries in the Milky Way
summary: Scientists created the most accurate three-dimensional map of star-formation regions in our Milky Way galaxy, based on data from the European Space Agency’s Gaia space telescope. This map will teach us more about these obscure cloudy areas, and the hot young stars that shape them.
detailed_news: Scientists have created the most accurate three-dimensional map of star-formation regions in our Milky Way galaxy. It is based on data from the European Space Agency’s Gaia space telescope. The map extends to a distance of 4000 light-years from us, with the Sun at the centre.

title: Keys to the Moon: ESA hands over third European Service Module
summary: Teams from ESA, Airbus, NASA and Lockheed Martin stand before the service module for Artemis III at NASA's Kennedy Space Center.
detailed_news: The third European Service Module was integrated by Airbus in Bremen, Germany, with contributions from industry all over Europe. The module will power Orion on Artemis III, the mission set to return astronauts to the lunar surface for the first time in over 50 years. The handover took place on 10 September at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center.

title: Moon geology lessons for Artemis
summary: Cindy Evans, Artemis lead for geology training, and Juliane Gross, Artemis sample curation lead, joined the PANGAEA training in the Lofoten islands, Norway, in july 2025.
detailed_news: ESA’s PANGAEA course has provided astronauts with Earth and planetary geology knowledge since 2016. The course has trained 16 astronauts from four space agencies to become effective partners for scientists and engineers in designing and executing future exploration missions. Cindy Evans and Juliane Gross lead geology training and sample curation for Artemis III, the next mission to return humans to the Moon.

title: A cell’s-eye view of altered gravity and ageing
summary: Muscle weakening, bone density loss and an impaired immune system: the systemic health impacts of spaceflight bear many similarities to ageing. Sharon van Rijthoven, a student from Delft University of Technology and Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, compared the effects of ageing and altered gravity from a cellular perspective during her internship at the European Space Agency (ESA).
detailed_news: Sharon van Rijthoven, a student from Delft University of Technology and Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, compared the effects of ageing and altered gravity from a cellular perspective. When astronauts visit the International Space Station (ISS), they experience a weightless environment. The lack of gravity means that the bones and muscles that support and move the body do not need to work as hard.

title: CNES Call Reveals Inaugural Callisto Flight Test Pushed to 2027
summary:
A 12 September call for proposals published by the French space agency CNES has revealed that the inaugural flight of the Callisto reusable rocket demonstrator has slipped from 2026 to 2027. Conceived in 2015, the Cooperative Action Leading to Launcher Innovation in Stage Toss-back Operations (Callisto) project is a collaboration between CNES, DLR, and JAXA […]
The post CNES Call Reveals Inaugural Callisto Flight Test Pushed to 2027 appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Callisto will stand 14 metres tall, with a width of 1.1 metres and a takeoff mass of 3,500 kilograms. It will include an integration phase followed by eight test flights and two demonstration flights, all to be completed over a period of eight months. Themis, Europe’s other, more capable reusable rocket demonstrator, is likely to conduct its initial hop tests from Esrange in Sweden.

title: NASA Sets Launch Coverage for Space Weather Missions
summary: NASA will provide live coverage of prelaunch and launch activities for an observatory designed to study space weather and explore and map the boundaries of our solar neighborhood. Launching with IMAP (Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe) are two rideshare missions, NASA’s Carruthers Geocorona Observatory and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Space Weather Follow […]
detailed_news: NASA will provide live coverage of prelaunch and launch activities for an observatory designed to study space weather. The IMAP spacecraft will study how the Sun’s energy and particles interact with the heliosphere. The Carruthers Geocorona Observatory is a small satellite that will observe the outermost atmospheric layer, the exosphere. Launch day coverage of the mission will be available on the agency’s website. Audio-only of the launch coverage will be carried on the NASA “V’ circuits. Members of the public can register to attend this launch virtually. Let people know you’re watching the mission on X, Facebook, and Instagram.

title: Launch Roundup: Starlink, NRO, and New Shepard missions scheduled
summary:
Another busy week of launches has arrived, with SpaceX dominating the launch manifest with four…
The post Launch Roundup: Starlink, NRO, and New Shepard missions scheduled appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX has four missions scheduled for the week. Three of these missions will see new batches of Starlink internet satellites launched into the company’s Starlink constellation. The fourth mission will launch a payload for the National Reconnaissance Office. Blue Origin will finally launch its uncrewed NS-35 mission on New Shepard on Thursday. Falcon 9 will launch 28 Starlink v2 Mini satellites into the constellation’s Group 10 shell, which is in a 53.16-degree inclination LEO. After liftoff and stage separation, B1088 will reenter Earth's atmosphere and land on SpaceX's droneship Of Course I Still Love You. B1092 will be flying for the seventh time, after supporting the NROL-69, CRS-32, GPS III SV08, USSF-36 and two Starlink missions (Groups 12-13 and 10-34) The NROL-48 mission for the National Reconnaissance Office is scheduled for Sunday, Sept. 21. Falcon 9 will fly the payload, a batch of Starshield satellites developed by SpaceX for government and military use, southeast out of Vandenberg into an orbit inclined 70 degrees. Falcon booster B1081 will fly for the 18th time on this mission after a 30-day turnaround.

title: NASA Awards Safety, Mission Assurance Services Contract
summary: NASA has selected Bastion Technologies Inc. of Houston to provide safety and mission assurance services for the agency’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. The Safety and Mission Assurance II (SMAS II) award is a performance-based, indefinite-delivery/indefinite-quantity contract with a maximum potential value of $400 million. A phase-in period begins Monday, followed by a […]
detailed_news: Bastion Technologies Inc. of Houston will provide safety and mission assurance services. The work will support various spaceflight and science missions. A phase-in period begins Monday, followed by a base ordering period of four years with options to extend services through March 2034.

title: NASA Analysis Shows Sun’s Activity Ramping Up
summary: It looked like the Sun was heading toward a historic lull in activity. That trend flipped in 2008, according to new research. The Sun has become increasingly active since 2008, a new NASA study shows. Solar activity is known to fluctuate in cycles of 11 years, but there are longer-term variations that can last decades. […]
detailed_news: The Sun has become increasingly active since 2008, a new NASA study shows. Trend could lead to an uptick in space weather events, such as solar storms, flares, and coronal mass ejections. Space weather predictions are critical for supporting the spacecraft and astronauts of NASA’s Artemis campaign. Two primary sources — ACE (Advanced Composition Explorer) and the Wind mission — launched in the 1990s and have been providing data on solar activity. The spacecraft belong to a fleet of NASA Heliophysics Division missions designed to study the Sun’s influence on space, Earth, and other planets.

title: Connecting Educators with NASA Data: Learning Ecosystems Northeast in Action
summary: One of the challenges many teachers face year after year is a sense of working alone. Despite the constant interaction with students many questions often linger: Did the lesson stick? Will students carry this knowledge with them? Will it shape how they see and engage with the world? What can be easy to overlook is […]
detailed_news: Connected Learning Ecosystems (CLEs) exist wherever learning happens. CLEs are the collective of people who contribute to a young person’s growth and education. Nearly 70 educators from across the northeast came together for two amazingly energized days of connection, learning, and future planning. Connected Learning Ecosystems (LEE) is a network of peer communities for educators across the Northeast. LENE is supported by NASA under cooperative agreement award number NNX16AB94A and is part of NASA's Science Activation Portfolio. This year's LENE conference was held in Portland, Maine.

title: Curiosity Blog, Sols 4655-4660: Boxworks With a View
summary: Written by Sharon Wilson Purdy, Planetary Geologist at the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum Earth planning date: Friday Sept. 12, 2025 Curiosity continues to image, analyze, and traverse through a landscape characterized by higher standing ridges separating low-lying depressions (hollows) — a surface known as the boxwork terrain on Mount Sharp. The science team […]
detailed_news: Geologist Sharon Wilson Purdy served as the Geology theme group “Keeper of the Plan” for Sols 4656-4657. ChemCam used its LIBS instrument to analyze the chemistry of a bedrock ridge at the “Quechua” target. Mastcam and ChemCam included several mosaics to document walls of nearby hollow interiors.
